content: I sometimes wonder what ever happened to the donut Dolly's that used to come out into the boonies and entertain us over in Nam. Most of the games they thought up to entertain us were silly games but it certainly was nice to see American Women and it took our minds off the war for an hour. Some of them recorded the newest rock music before they left the States and played it for us when they landed in the field. Made us all homesick. Hope all of them made it home okay.
reply: I sometimes wonder what ever happened to the donut Dolly's that used to come out into the boonies and entertain us over in Nam. Most of the games they thought up to entertain us were silly games but it certainly was nice to see American Women and it took our minds off the war for an hour. Some of them recorded the newest rock music before they left the States and played it for us when they landed in the field. Made us all homesick. Hope all of them made it home okay.
title: Donut Dolly's

content: They didn't. One died of disease, one in a jeep wreck and one was murdered. Here's a list of all the women who died during that war. I never knew about all of them. 'http://www.illyria.com/women/vnwlist.html'
reply: They didn't. One died of disease, one in a jeep wreck and one was murdered. Here's a list of all the women who died during that war. I never knew about all of them. 'http://www.illyria.com/women/vnwlist.html'
title: Donut Dolly's

content: Sorry to hear they are not around anymore! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: Sorry to hear they are not around anymore! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: Donut Dolly's

content: My first experience with the Red Cross “Donut Dolly’s” was in Korea in 1962. They faithfully visited our missile site once about every two weeks and only missed a couple a visits due to restrictions on travel due to weather conditions. They brought a few dozen boxes of donuts and our mess provided the fresh coffee which was especially welcome during the cold winter months. They usually stayed for an hour or so and brought games, newspapers, magazines and provided conversation to the troops. This was a great morale booster as for many of the troops as it was the only American females they had contact with during their entire 13 month tour. Our missile site was near the DMZ and I recall the “Dolly’s” arriving wearing steel pots several times when we were on high alert.
reply: My first experience with the Red Cross “Donut Dolly’s” was in Korea in 1962. They brought a few dozen boxes of donuts and our mess provided the fresh coffee which was especially welcome during the cold winter months. They usually stayed for an hour or so and brought games, newspapers, magazines and provided conversation to the troops. This was a great morale booster as for many of the troops as it was the only American females they had contact with during their entire 13 month tour. Our missile site was near the DMZ and I recall the “Dolly’s” arriving wearing steel pots several times when we were on high alert.
title: Donut Dolly's

content: All of them that I met were super nice and not necessary beautiful but nice looking and lots of fun. Some had to have steel pots on but did their best to not act afraid. Was nice to have a small touch of home.
reply: All of them that I met were super nice and not necessary beautiful but nice looking and lots of fun. Some had to have steel pots on but did their best to not act afraid. Was nice to have a small touch of home.
title: Donut Dolly's

content: Richard I never saw a Donut Dolly come to our field location my entire tour (8 months) in VN. However when we arrived at Cu Chi for a stand down they were usually there to greet us with flags, kool-aid, cookies and stuff. I don’t think I ever stopped for even a kool-aid after getting off the choppers; the base bar was my watering hole. They were good people but I felt had little use being in VN. The only celebrity I saw was Fess Parker, he was the only one who came to the field, I never saw any other celebrity’s as they entertained at the base camps. I can’t blame them, the field was not a safe place to be, not even a fire support base. There was a Donut Dolly who came to a Wolfhound Reunion I attented. I think her name was Susan.
reply: Richard I never saw a Donut Dolly come to our field location my entire tour (8 months) in VN. However when we arrived at Cu Chi for a stand down they were usually there to greet us with flags, kool-aid, cookies and stuff. I can’t blame them, the field was not a safe place to be, not even a fire support base. There was a Donut Dolly who came to a Wolfhound Reunion I attented. I think her name was Susan.
title: Donut Dolly's

content: We had Donut Dolly's at our base camp at An Khe in 67. I believe they set up at the USO shed there. I only spent a total of about 3 weeks at An Khe my whole time with the Cav but I do remember sitting down, reading books, enjoying the AC, and talking to those girls. I am thankful for all of them that took the trip.
reply: We had Donut Dolly's at our base camp at An Khe in 67. I believe they set up at the USO shed there. I only spent a total of about 3 weeks at An Khe my whole time with the Cav but I do remember sitting down, reading books, enjoying the AC, and talking to those girls. I am thankful for all of them that took the trip.
title: Donut Dolly's

content: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: We had Donut Dolly's at our base camp at An Khe in 67. I believe they set up at the USO shed there. I only spent a total of about 3 weeks at An Khe my whole time with the Cav but I do remember sitting down, reading books, enjoying the AC, and talking to those girls. I am thankful for all of them that took the trip. They came once to a little firebase out in the Que Son's where I spent the last month or so of my tour. They brought a small Conex container slung under a Skycrane which was a little mini-PX of sorts. The games were silly, but I really liked the girls. Hell, after that long without seeing a round-eye, Rosie O'Donnel would have looked good! But, seriously folks, those girls deserve a great big tip o' the steel pot. None of them HAD to be there.
quote: Originally posted by Duster6: We had Donut Dolly's at our base camp at An Khe in 67. I believe they set up at the USO shed there. I only spent a total of about 3 weeks at An Khe my whole time with the Cav but I do remember sitting down, reading books, enjoying the AC, and talking to those girls. I am thankful for all of them that took the trip.

Hell, after that long without seeing a round-eye, Rosie O'Donnel would have looked good! But, seriously folks, those girls deserve a great big tip o' the steel pot. None of them HAD to be there.

content: Thats right, none of them had to be there but they came and they stayed and like Kit said, just being there gave us a feeling of being home. I too salute them.
reply: Thats right, none of them had to be there but they came and they stayed and like Kit said, just being there gave us a feeling of being home. I too salute them.
title: Donut Dolly's

content: never saw any Donut Dollies but a group of old ladies got together and sent us a bunch of those "penny toys", you know, those little cardboard pinball games type of things.. we all got a little gift; they were silly things but like several of you have already said it made us feel good that someone, somewhere, spent the effort and time to send something to a group of soldiers they didn't know anything about. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE
reply: never saw any Donut Dollies but a group of old ladies got together and sent us a bunch of those "penny toys", you know, those little cardboard pinball games type of things.. we all got a little gift; they were silly things but like several of you have already said it made us feel good that someone, somewhere, spent the effort and time to send something to a group of soldiers they didn't know anything about. One Flag......One Heart......One Nation............EVERMORE
title: Donut Dolly's

content: We had some stationed at PhanRan They would come out on the flightline with cookies and donuts.It was nice to see them there.
reply: We had some stationed at PhanRan They would come out on the flightline with cookies and donuts.It was nice to see them there.
title: Donut Dolly's

content: quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: never saw any Donut Dollies but a group of old ladies got together and sent us a bunch of those "penny toys", you know, those little cardboard pinball games type of things.. we all got a little gift; they were silly things but like several of you have already said it made us feel good that someone, somewhere, spent the effort and time to send something to a group of soldiers they didn't know anything about. I got a Christmas package (1970) addressed to "any soldier" from a garden club in West Baton Rouge, LA. It had a bunch of stuff in it, such as writing tablets, pens etc. Some of it wasn't really practical or useable, but the thought and effort behind it really lifted my spirits. It's easy to forget how much the little things mean to a soldier, isn't it?
quote: Originally posted by m551sheridan: never saw any Donut Dollies but a group of old ladies got together and sent us a bunch of those "penny toys", you know, those little cardboard pinball games type of things.. we all got a little gift; they were silly things but like several of you have already said it made us feel good that someone, somewhere, spent the effort and time to send something to a group of soldiers they didn't know anything about.

It's easy to forget how much the little things mean to a soldier, isn't it?
